moves.7. Bd3 a6 8. O-O dxc4 9. Bxc4 Nb6: According to grandmaster analysis of this opening, 9...P-QN4 is better.
moves.10. Bd3 Nfd5 11. Bxe7 Qxe7 12. Qd2: With White having a spatial advantage, moving the QN to avoid the exchange would keep Black more cramped.
moves.16. Qc2 h6 17. Rfe1 b6 18. Rb2 Rb8 19. R: Doubling the Rooks and severely pressuring the Q-side.
moves.19... Qd6 20. Qe2 a5: Now Reshevsky's backward QNP is fixed as a target.
moves.21. Bb5 Rd8 22. h3 Qc7: Reshevsky's position is becoming more and more cramped.
moves.23. e4 Nf8 24. Qe3 Bd7: Any exchanges will help ease the stranglehold Janowski has on the position.
moves.25. Ne5 Be8 26. Bxe8 Rdxe8 27. f4: Janowski switches the focus of the attack to the K-side.
moves.27... f6 28. Nf3 Nd7 29. e5 f5: Reshevsky attempts to slow the attack.
moves.30. g4 g6 31. gxf5 gxf5: Now a new avenue of attack opens for Janowski.
moves.32. d5 Nf8 33. Rg2+ Kh7 34. c4 Qf7: Reshevsky hastens to defend the threatened flank.
moves.37... Qb7: According to post-mortem analysis by the players, Janowski could have won here with 38 N-N5 ch. But over-the-board, he misses the move.
moves.40... hxg5 41. fxg5 Ng6: This move holds the position... for the moment.
moves.42. Rg2g3 Kg7 43. Rh3 Rgh8 44. hxg6 Rxh3: More post-mortem analysis showed that 45 QxR would give White an easy draw. But again, Janowski misses the move.
moves.45. Kxh3 Rh8+ 46. Kg3 Qxa4: Now Reshevsky also hass a passed Pawn.
moves.50. Kg3 Qd3+ 51. Kg2 Qe2+ 52. Kg3 Qh2+ 5: Wins the Queen. But Janowski still has drawing chances.
moves.54. Qf6+ Kg8 55. d7 Rxf6+: Here Janowski misses his last opportunity to draw. Post-mortem analysis revealed that the only move to hold the position for White is 56 KPxR!
moves.56. gxf6: Again, Janowski cannot find the correct move over the board.
moves.56... Qd2 57. Rh1 Qd3+ 58. Kg2: The King cannot go to the B file.
moves.58... Qxg6+: Now Janowski's QP will also fall.
moves.64. Rg1+ Kf8 65. Kg5 Qd4: Janowski resigns. Magnificently played by Reshevsky after a very bad start.
